metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Juggilal Kamalapat

facts.text: Prior to assessment year 1943-44, three Singhania brothers (Sir Padampat Singhania, Kamlapat Singhania, Lakshmipat Singhania) carried on hosiery business in name of Juggilal Kamalapat with Head Office at Kanpur and branch at Calcutta.
On November 29, 1939, three brothers executed deed of partnership taking Jhabbarmal Saraf as partner with equal shares.
On October 27, 1941, three brothers executed Kamla Town Trust deed for welfare of employees of Juggilal Kamalapat Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd., with brothers as first trustees.

On December 2, 1942, three brothers executed Deed of Relinquishment relinquishing rights to all properties and assets of firm Juggilal Kamalapat in favour of Jhabbarmal Saraf and themselves as trustees of Kamla Town Trust, recognizing earlier oral relinquishment effective from March 26, 1942.

On December 1, 1942, Partnership Deed executed between Jhabbarmal Saraf and Kamla Town Trust (represented by three trustees), constituting partnership effective March 27, 1942, with shares: Kamla Town Trust 3/4, Jhabbarmal Saraf 1/4.

Firm Juggilal Kamalapat owned movable and immovable properties at Belur near Calcutta, including lands and buildings for hosiery factory, shown in balance-sheet as firm properties; expenses for maintenance/additions claimed with depreciation.

New partnership applied for registration under s.26A Income Tax Act for 1943-44; ITO rejected; AAC upheld on different reasons; Tribunal upheld on grounds: unregistered Relinquishment Deed invalid for immovables (inseparable from business), not notified to banks, not registered with Registrar of Firms till May 1946; Trust introduced Rs.50,000 as capital.

Tribunal referred question to Calcutta High Court: 'Whether on the above facts and in the circumstances of this case, the partnership, as evidenced by the Deed of 1st December 1942, legally came into existence and as such should be registered?'; HC remanded twice for supplementary statements; finally answered in favour of firm based on admissions and facts in para 6 of statement dated 13th March 1952, no legal flaw in constitution.
Commissioner filed appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under s.66A(2) Income Tax Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the partnership, as evidenced by the Deed of 1st December 1942, legally came into existence and as such should be registered under s.26A Income Tax Act?
Whether non-registration of Relinquishment Deed invalidates transfer of business assets to new partnership?
Can registration application be rejected merely on ground that business assets were not legally transferred to new partnership?

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal recorded finding of fact that firm seeking registration (Kamla Town Trust and Jhabbarmal Saraf) was not a genuine firm and had never come into existence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.66 Income Tax Act (question of fact not referable)

petitioner_arguments.text: Relinquishment Deed dated 2nd December 1942, being unregistered, could not legally transfer rights and title to immovables owned by firm to Kamla Town Trust; transfer ineffective and immovables inseparable from other assets, so entire business not transferred.
New firm constitution not notified to banks dealing with old firm; new partnership not registered with Registrar of Firms till May 1946.

respondent_arguments.text: Deed of relinquishment did not require registration as partner's interest in firm assets (including immovables) is movable property.

court_reasoning.text: Referred question was purely legal (validity in law), not factual existence; Tribunal did not find no factual existence, so HC correctly confined to legal aspect; firm existed in fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Existence of firm can be challenged on factual or legal grounds; reference only on law.

court_reasoning.text: Kamla Town Trust constituted; partnership deed executed specifying partners (Trust via trustees, Saraf) and shares; Trust introduced Rs.50,000 capital; valid partnership on these facts alone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partnership deed and capital contribution suffice.

court_reasoning.text: Deed of Relinquishment transfers individual interest of partners in firm assets, treated as movable property even if firm owns immovables; no registration required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Addanki Narayanappa: partner's interest ceases to be exclusive property, becomes trading asset.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Relinquishment invalid for immovables, valid for movables (separable); firm owns movables plus Rs.50,000 capital.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deed separable like gift, not partition.

holdings.text: Partnership as evidenced by Deed of 1st December 1942 legally came into existence; no impediment to registration under s.26A.
Deed evidencing transfer of partner's interest in partnership assets (movables and immovables) does not require registration.
Registration cannot be rejected merely because business assets not fully legally transferred if movables transferred and capital contributed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Addanki Narayanappa and Another v. Bhaskara Krishnappa (dead) and thereafter his heirs, and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Partner's interest in partnership assets (including immovables) is movable property; no registration required under s.17(1) Registration Act for transfer of such interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Addanki Narayanappa Anr. v. Bhaskara Krishtappa Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench Andhra Pradesh HC view upheld by SC on partner's interest as movable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ajudhia Pershad Ram Pershad v. Sham Sunder and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench Lahore HC: partner's interest in partnership regarded as movable property under O.21 r.49 CPC despite immovable assets.

precedents_cited.case_name: Perumal Ammal v. Perumal Naicker Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Madras HC: deed of gift/relinquishment separable; invalidity as to one property does not affect others.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of firm; reference to HC on question of law; certificate for appeal to SC.

statutes_cited.name: Registration Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Whether deed transferring partner's interest requires registration.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Concept of partnership: property brought in becomes trading asset; partner's right to share of profits.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Partner's interest treated as movable for attachment/sale.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the Commissioner's appeal, upholding Calcutta High Court's answer that the partnership legally came into existence with no impediment to registration under s.26A, based on validity of partnership deed, capital contribution, and non-requiring registration of relinquishment deed for partner's interest.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs (as per HC; not specified in SC).

key_quotes.text: "The whole concept of partnership is to embark upon a joint venture and for that purpose to bring in as capital money or even property including immovable property. Once that is done, whatever is brought in would cease to be the exclusive property of the person who brought it in."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why partner's interest in firm assets is movable, no registration needed.

key_quotes.text: "A deed of relinquishment is in the nature of a deed of gift, where the various properties dealt with are always separable, and the invalidity of the deed of gift in respect of one item cannot affect its validity in respect of another."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies separability of movable and immovable assets in relinquishment.

key_quotes.text: "Regard being had to the admissions made on behalf of the department, the facts and circumstances mentioned in paragraph 6 of the statement of case dated 13th March 1952 do not show that there was any legal flaw in the constitution of the partnership firm."
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: HC's final answer favoring registration, upheld by SC.
